routing_summary.excerpt_summary: Section 8 defines the common fixed header and variable options area for DHCPv6 client/server messages, including the msg-type, transaction-id, and options layout, and references the message type list (Section 7.3) and option definitions (Section 21).

Temporal.explanation: Pure format description; no sequencing, timers, or state transitions involved.

ActorDirectionality.explanation: Only says “between clients and servers” at a structural level; no send/receive role logic to check here.

Scope.explanation: Scope is clearly “client/server messages” (not relay), and references to Sections 7.3 and 21 are appropriate.

Causal.explanation: The format is straightforward and standard; no algorithmic cause→effect chains or behaviors that could break if misread.

Quantitative.explanation: Field sizes (1 octet msg-type, 3 octet transaction-id, options = total message size − 4 octets) are self-consistent and match existing DHCPv6 practice.

Deontic.explanation: No normative behavior (MUST/SHOULD) in this section, just descriptive structure.

Structural.explanation: The bit diagram matches the prose and aligns with the generic option format in Section 21.1; no ABNF/YANG/etc. to cross-check here.

CrossRFC.explanation: References (7.3 for types, 21 for options) are correct and in-scope; no external RFC numbers here.

Terminology.explanation: Uses existing terms (msg-type, transaction-id, options) consistently with the rest of the draft and RFC 8415 lineage.

Boundary.explanation: No edge cases or bounds behavior (e.g., empty option set) that would need additional rules; empty or minimal messages still have a well-defined structure.
